skills.name: Calculate proportions of total frequency from a box plot
Describe the shape of data when presented visually
Compare differences in averages as a multiple of variability (US)

explanations.A: I think you have performed the division in the wrong order, dividing the MAD by the difference in means (2.4 รท 6).
explanations.B: The difference between the means is 50 - 44 = 6 hours. To express this as a multiple of Brand A's variability, you calculate the ratio: 6 / 2.4 = 2.5.
explanations.C: This is the difference between the two means (50 - 44 = 6), but you haven't completed the final step of expressing this difference as a multiple of the variability.
explanations.D: I think you have divided the mean of brand A by the mean of brand B. We want to know what the difference is between these means, and what multiple of 2.4 it is.

explanations.A: I think you have divided the mean of brand A by the mean of brand B. We want to know what the difference is between these means, and what multiply of 1.6 it is.
explanations.B: I think you have performed the division in the wrong order, dividing the MAD by the difference in means (1.6 รท 6).
explanations.C: I think you have divided the mean of brand B by the mean of brand A. We want to know what the difference is between these means, and what multiple of 1.6 it is.
explanations.D: The difference between the means is 33 - 27 = 6 hours. To express this as a multiple of Brand A's variability, you calculate the ratio: 6/1.6=3.75

explanations.A: I think you used the upper quartile rather than the median when finding the difference in medians. Remember the median is the middle line
explanations.B: The median for restaurant A is 50, and for restaurant B it is 70. The difference is therefore 20. The interquartile range for A is 55 - 45 = 10. Dividing 20 by 10 we get 2.0
explanations.C: I think you found the interquartile range. We need to know what multiple of the interquartile range will give us the difference in the medians.
explanations.D: I think you found the difference between the medians. We need to know what multiple of the interquartile range will give us the difference in the medians.

explanations.A: I think you found the difference between the medians. We need to know what multiple of the interquartile range will give us the difference in the medians.
explanations.B: I think you used the upper quartile rather than the median when finding the difference in medians. Remember the median is the middle line
explanations.C: The median for restaurant A is 55, and for restaurant B it is 85. The difference is therefore 30. The interquartile range for A is 60 - 50 = 10. Dividing 30 by 10 we get 3.0
explanations.D: I think you found the interquartile range. We need to know what multiple of the interquartile range will give us the difference in the medians.

explanations.A: I think you believe a lower mode is related to longer sleep. Points further to the right represent a longer sleep.
explanations.B: The mode for no device is 6 hours, but for no device it is 8 hours. Also more of the points are to the left for device. Therefore those without a device sleep longer.
explanations.C: I think you are comparing the spread rather than the amount of sleep. Look at where the points are for each group, remembering points to the right represent longer sleep.
explanations.D: You can look at the general shape to see who gets more sleep. Remember points further to the right represent longer sleep.

explanations.A: You can look at the general shape to see who gets more sleep. Remember points further to the right represent longer sleep.
explanations.B: I think you are comparing the spread rather than the amount of sleep. Look at where the points are for each group, remembering points to the right represent longer sleep.
explanations.C: The modes for no device are 7 and 9 hours, but for device it is 6 and 7 hours. Also more of the points are to the left for device. Therefore those with a device sleep less.
explanations.D: I think you believe a lower mode is related to longer sleep. Points further to the right represent a longer sleep.

explanations.A: While this statement is a true calculation about the variability of each group (Year 9 range is 10-6=4; Year 10 range is 9-5=4), it describes the spread of the data, not the overlap between the two data sets, which is what the question asks for.
explanations.B: This is a comparison of the centers of the two groups. While likely true, it is not a description of the visual overlap. The question specifically asks how the data sets overlap, not for a final conclusion about which group sleeps more.
explanations.C: This is true. There is a large overlap, with most of the dots in both groups falling between 6 and 9.
explanations.D: This conclusion is based on a single data point at the extreme end of one distribution. We need to look at how much overlap there is between all the points in both groups.

explanations.A: This conclusion is based on a single data point at the extreme end of one distribution. We need to look at how much overlap there is between all the points in both groups.
explanations.B: This is true. There is a large overlap, with most of the dots in both groups falling between 7 and 11.
explanations.C: While this statement is a true calculation about the variability of each group (Year 10 range is 11-6=5; Year 11 range is 12-7=5), it describes the spread of the data, not the overlap between the two data sets, which is what the question asks for.
explanations.D: This is a comparison of the centers of the two groups. While likely true, it is not a description of the visual overlap. The question specifically asks how the data sets overlap, not for a final conclusion about which group has more screen time.

explanations.A: I think you were just looking at the tail of the swimmers. Think about how many quartiles overlap.
explanations.B: There is full overlap for the top 25% of swimmers, and there is partial overlap for the next 25% of swimmers too, which means that between 25% and 50% of the heights overlap.
explanations.C: I think you were just considering the boxes. Remember the tails represent 25% of the group too. Think about how many quartiles overlap.
explanations.D: I think you may have double counted sections. Think about how many quartiles overlap.

explanations.A: I think you were just considering the boxes. Remember the tails represent 25% of the group too. Think about how many quartiles overlap.
explanations.B: I think you were just looking at the tail of the gymnasts. Think about how many quartiles overlap.
explanations.C: There is full overlap for the top quartile of gymnasts, and there is partial overlap for the next quartile too, which means that between 25% and 50% of the heights overlap.
explanations.D: I think you may have double counted sections. Think about how many quartiles overlap.
